children.subject: Matrix Algebra (inverse, subspaces, dimension and rank, etc), Determinants, Vector Spaces (Bases, linear independence, column/null space) Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues

^ blatantly insufficient

Please do not take EECS 127; it is an advanced upper-division undergraduate course, meant to be taken after completing lower div requirements.

They are missing SVD, PCA, eigendecomposition, PSD matrices, and (probably) mathematical maturity in these areas, the most important of them all. I took Math 54, Math 110, CS189, and EE16A before EE127 and still found the linear algebra somewhat challenging.
You really need a decent exposure with linear algebra before to feel comfortable.
Can you elaborate more on what parts of linear you are comfortable with

history.content: From what I hear from students who've taken 127, they describe it as "Linear Algebra on Steroids." If you have no background in Lin. Alg. (even Math 110 is recommended for it for mathematical maturity), I highly do not recommend taking it.

children.subject: +1 unless you feel your theoretical lin alg (not just mechanical techniques) is strong

IMO, math 110 (with stankova) is not a good class. It is a good class for learning how rigorous you need to be for proofs (which is a good thing) but not for linear algebra skills involving applications. That being said, it can't hurt, but I would take 16AB instead.
I've taken 16AB—speaking for myself, even after getting an A on both finals I still don't feel like I have the preparation for EECS127, because the class is more application-focused than theoretical

That opinion is valid (I've not taken 16B but can only look at its lecture syllabus, but have taken 16A), but for certain Math 110 isn't very helpful at all.

Honestly, the class that prepared me the most was CS189, but at least with the future CS189 you should take EE127 first. The reality of the situation is you'll need to study immensely to get up to par. But there's no way you should be taking 127 without at least a decent amount of linear algebra exposure.
What's the difference between CS 189 in the future? Also I heard that Sahai 189 is vastly different from other iterations because he assumes 126/127 experience.

Are you asking the differences between CS189 now and what it was before Sahai? By the way, credit also goes to Stella Yu since she taught it too, but for brevity I will just say Sahai.

I personally took CS189 with Shewchuk and then was an academic intern for 189 under Sahai (and next semester I will be TA'ing 189). To me, the difference seemed to be in that Shewhcuk would focus a great deal more on the concepts than the rigorous math (which Sahai focused on a lot). Both, in my opinion, have their benefits, but Sahai's in my opinion is the way to go forward. It's not that Shewchuk's iteration didn't have rigorous math, but Sahai's iteration did really show how important the mathematical details and rigorousness are to understand where the approaches we talk about come from. 

I would not say that Sahai's iteration "assumes 126/127". It moreso assumes EE16A/B, CS70, foundations in linear algebra, probability, optimization, and multvariable calculus, mathematical maturity in general, proper study habits, and a drive to deeply understand the material. EE126/7 are certainly very helpful for some of this, and they CERTAINLY will let you make the most out of your experience with CS189, but I would not say they are assumed.

The way Sahai describes it is that students should have already have passed through these foundations in some form in previous classes. CS189 should probably be your 3rd pass in linear algebra, 3rd pass in probability, (maybe) ~2nd pass in optimization, and 2nd pass in multivariable calculus. That way, you really maintain this rigorousness and understand a lot of the important details in order to truly appreciate the material.
I will be taking 110 with Frenkel. Is there anything I should focus in the course to better prepare for 127?

@above Anon:  developing mathematical maturity.  I know this is an unsatisfying answer, but perhaps more concrete actions are:

-Actually understanding proofs instead of choosing to gloss over them

-Being comfortable with abstract concepts and finding ways to have them "make sense" to you (ex. working in higher dimensions, Fundamental Theorem of Linear Algebra, what it really means to have linearly dependent rows and columns or an ill-conditioned matrix, change of basis)

-Essentially, push yourself to learn more than just mechanical techniques, algebraic manipulations, and pattern-matching on exams to just "get by".  That's not to say the mechanical stuff is not important; they are, too.
Don't recommend it at all. You will not properly enjoy it.

history.content: I'm familiar with basic concepts of Linear Algebra but have not taken a Linear Algebra course in Berkeley yet. Looking at the syllabus for 127, a portion of the class seems to cover Linear Algebra so I'm not sure if I should take 54/110/16AB first or if it would be alright to just take 127.
history.subject: EECS 127 without Math 54 and 16AB
